habitat_description:
The range of this species is restricted to southwestern Texas (Hill Country, Trans-Pecos), and northeastern Mexico. Populations occur in the southwestern Edwards Plateau of Texas, the Stockton Plateau, and the Big Bend region well into the Davis Mountains. In Mexico, its range extends along Coahuila to the front range of Sierra Madre Oriental of Coahuila and Nuevo Leon, also found in the Sierra San Carlos of Tamaulipas, at elevations of approximately 305-3050 meters (Lawson and Lieb 1990; Werler and Dixon 2000). Records for this species remain sporadic (Tennant 1998), but may not describe actual occurrences but instead be due to the secretive behavior of the species (Ernst and Ernst 2003).

This species is associated with bare rock, scree, talus, various woodland types, shrubland, and chaparral environments. This is a snake known to burrow using soil, fallen logs, leaf debris, standing snag, and hollow trees. Its habitats of preference are characterized by rocky, igneus, or limestone environments. In particular, this species occurs in habitats with caves, canyon walls, deep crevices, and also wooded crevices in association with ranch outbuildings (Lawson and Lieb 1990). In Texas, this species inhabits the wooded rocky canyons of the Edwards Plateau, barren road-cut bluffs with scattered seep willow, mesic canyons in montane forest and lowland desert areas of the Trans-Pecos region, and also in the pinyon pine-needle grass uplands in the Chisos Mountains (Tennant 1984; 1998). Vegetation associations are characteristic of the Chihuahuan desert scrub in Texas to Sierra Madrean pine forest in Tamaulipas, Mexico (Lawson and Lieb 1990).

SW	-Chihuahuan desert scrub in Texas to Sierra Madrean pine forest in Tamaulipas (Lawson and Lieb 1990).
